text: Hospital course notable for the following: -	ruled in for MI with peak Tn=0.96 -	LLE thrombectomy -	Right to left femoral PTFE graft -	Discovery of possible embolization from the left endograft limb -	Development of postoperative compartment syndrome, requiring fasciotomies of all 4 compartments -	HIT positivity -	DM management by Dr. Phelps -	Extubation postoperatively, with reintubation POD #3 2/2 inability to protect airway -	Aspiration events, PNA -	Sepsis, requiring pressors MRSA -	Septic emboli in L lung -	Pneumonia Pseudomonas, Klebsiella -	Difficult vent weaning -	Tracheostomy placement, eventual decanulation -	Failure of multiple swallowing trials -	G-tube placement -	Renal failure, improved when decreased diuresis -	Conjunctivitis, bacterial endophthalmitis -	Wound Care for chronic LLE wounds -	Likely graft infection with the decision to treat with Rifampin and Bactrim for 2 months 3/15/94: transferred to KH -	multiple episodes of TF emesis, cough, gagging, O2 sat 80% RA rx'd with sxn, O2, Zofran -	3/18/94 patient developed severe hypoxia O2 sat 70% RA.

text: A/P: Pt is a 69 yo F with PMH notable for DM, HTN, peripheral neuropathy and s/p MI with multiple admissions for rule out, who presents with chest pain, shortness of breath, nightsweats, dizziness, and new mediastinal lymphadenopathy with a lung nodule not noted on prior chest X-rays.
label: DIABETES:after_DCT:mention:null:null

text: This constellation of symptoms may be viewed in several different ways: from a cardiac standpoint, as presentation of unstable angina, given her hx of MI and cardiac risk factors; from an oncological standpoint, as a pheochromocytoma or carcinoid syndrome, given the sympathomimetic nature of her symptoms such as dizziness, abd pain/nausea, chest pain and dyspnea, and the findings in Ab CT and Chest CT, or a primary lung cancer given her history of smoking; from an infectious disease standpoint, as possible reactivation tuberculosis, given that she has a history of TB infection and treatment.
label: CAD:before_DCT:event:null:null

text: I believe the priority of the differential should be granted to the oncologic and infectious etiologies, given that she appears to be ruling out for an MI, has little to no ischemic changes on EKG, and is chest pain free with continued exacerbation of her shortness of breath and sweating.
label: CAD:before_DCT:event:null:null

text: He had an unremarkable electrocardiogram initially and negative cardiac markers, and was admitted to the medicine service to rule-out a myocardial infarction.
label: CAD:before_DCT:event:null:null

text: Additionally his next set of cardiac markers returned positive.
label: CAD:before_DCT:test:null:null

text: He therefore went cardiac catheterization revealing a total occlusion of his right coronary artery and minimal non-obstructive disease of the left system.
label: CAD:before_DCT:test:null:null

text: This artery was stented with total of three stents (two Express stents 2.5 x 24 mm and one Pixel stent 2.5 x 28 mm), encompassing the entire length of the right coronary artery.
label: CAD:before_DCT:event:null:null

text: He ruled in for myocardial infarction with a peak CK of 1490 and a peak troponin of 2.0.
label: CAD:before_DCT:event:null:null

text: His reduced ejection fraction was out of proportion to his degree of coronary disease.
label: CAD:after_DCT:mention:null:null

text: Since his myocardial infarction, Mr. Urban has been feeling quite well.
label: CAD:before_DCT:event:null:null

text: Prior to his admission, he did not have any known hypertension or hyperlipidemia, but has been diagnosed with these conditions while in the hospital.
label: HYPERTENSION:after_DCT:mention:null:null

text: His medications include aspirin 325 mg daily, Plavix 75 mg daily, Lipitor 20 mg daily, lisinopril 10 mg daily, and carvedilol 6.25 mg twice each day.
label: HYPERLIPIDEMIA:after_DCT:mention:null:null

text: He smoked 1 to 1-1/2 packs per day for about 30 years, but has not smoked since his hospitalization.
label: SMOKER:null:null:past:null

text: He has a family history of coronary artery disease in that his father had 3 myocardial infarctions and died at a young age of heart disease.
label: CAD:after_DCT:mention:null:null

text: His lipid panel from his hospitalization reveals total cholesterol of 210 mg/dl, LDL of 153 mg/dl, and HDL of 45mg/dl.
label: HYPERLIPIDEMIA:before_DCT:high_LDL:null:null

text: His nuclear images revealed a mild reduction in tracer activity in the inferior wall which persisted after reinjection consistent with his inferior myocardial infarction.
label: CAD:before_DCT:event:null:null

text: In short, Mr. Urban is a 51-year-old who had an inferior myocardial infarction, but interestingly during his hospitalization had systolic dysfunction well out of proportion to his coronary disease.
label: CAD:after_DCT:mention:null:null

text: Clearly this has manifested itself as an inferior myocardial infarction due to an occluded right coronary artery, which was treated during his hospitalization with stenting.
label: CAD:before_DCT:event:null:null

text: The other issue is his transient systolic dysfunction that is out of proportion to his coronary artery disease.
label: CAD:after_DCT:mention:null:null

text: From the aspect of his coronary artery disease, he will continue on aspirin for life.
label: CAD:after_DCT:mention:null:null

text: He received quite a substantial amount of stenting to his right coronary artery, and I would opt to continue his Plavix for at least 12 months.
label: MEDICATION:after_DCT:null:null:thienopyridine

text: For his hyperlipidemia, I agree with Lipitor, and we will recheck his lipid profile to see if the dose of Lipitor is adequate.
label: HYPERLIPIDEMIA:after_DCT:mention:null:null

text: He is well beta-blocked on his carvedilol, and we will continue with the current dose of 6.25 mg twice daily.
label: MEDICATION:after_DCT:null:null:beta_blocker

text: His blood pressure allows us to increase his lisinopril from 10 to 15 mg daily.
label: MEDICATION:after_DCT:null:null:ACE_inhibitor

text: In summary, well we do not have records, it is fairly clear that Mrs. Preston has had an inferior wall myocardial infarction treated with coronary stenting.
label: CAD:before_DCT:event:null:null

text: The good news is that appears that her left ventricular function is very well preserved suggesting that she did not have a large myocardial infarction.
label: CAD:before_DCT:event:null:null

text: What is less clear, however, is the status of her other coronaries, there is some suggestion that she may have significant coronary artery disease at this time.
label: CAD:after_DCT:mention:null:null

text: In terms of her lipids, it appears that she has been switched to Lipitor.
label: MEDICATION:after_DCT:null:null:statin

text: Therefore, she should certainly remain on aspirin for the remainder of her life and Plavix for an absolute minimum of one year.
label: MEDICATION:after_DCT:null:null:aspirin

text: After a year, it would likely be acceptable for her to stop her Plavix for brief periods of time should it be necessary for other medical procedures.

text: However, up until that time her Plavix should not be discontinued without a discussion with myself.

text: Plan: Diarrhea · Follow-up stool cultures · Support with IV fluids · Consider CT scan if w/u is negative Pancreatitis · Bowel rest, NPO · Aggressive IVF w/D5NS x 2 liters · Pain control with morphine prn (but discomfort is very mild) · Check RUQ US to assess for gallbladder/pancreatic pathology DM2 · ½ dose insulin while NPO · RISS · Consider adding very low dose ACE I after diarrhea resolves UTI: no sx or indication for abx.
